briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for December 22, 2025. Today's briefing will primarily cover domestic and international climate change response efforts, the deepening crisis, and the complexities of international cooperation.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡·ğŸŒ± Acceleration of Domestic Carbon Neutrality Implementation and Policy Developments
sections.content: As of December 22, 2025, the Republic of Korea continues its diverse efforts for the transition to a carbon-neutral society. At the national level, the 4th 'National Measures for Proactive Response to Climate Crisis' has been established, and the 2035 National Greenhouse Gas Reduction Target (NDC) has been confirmed, presenting more specific goals [6, 7]. The Ministry of Climate has launched a 'DXÂ·AX Strategy Task Force' utilizing artificial intelligence (AI) to accelerate the achievement of carbon neutrality goals, while the Korea Gas Safety Corporation is establishing a national standard (KS) for Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technology, thereby solidifying the technological foundation [19, 20]. Including Gunsan City's project to build energy self-sufficient infrastructure for achieving its 2025 carbon neutrality goal [23], Gangwon Self-Governing Province's climate response investments, such as those for drought [4], and Busan Nakdonggang Garden's collaboration on blue carbon utilization [9], various local governments and communities [1, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 18, 22, 25, 26, 28], as well as the financial sector [17, 21, 24], are also showing active movements towards implementing carbon neutrality. Furthermore, in the National Assembly, a bill to amend parts of the Framework Act on Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth for responding to the climate crisis has been proposed, and discussions on strengthening the legal and institutional foundations are also active [27].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡·âš ï¸ Progress and Challenges in South Korea's Domestic Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: As the climate crisis materializes, amidst the accelerating transition of domestic industrial and energy structures, efforts to transition to renewable energy are continuing [5]. In particular, Jeollanam-do, as the leading region in the renewable energy sector, is accelerating the fostering of new and renewable energy and advanced strategic industries through cooperation with the Korea Development Bank. To achieve the 100GW renewable energy target, it is also expediting the promotion of factory rooftop solar power generation and the review of the "Energy Highway" initiative's performance [29, 31, 33, 34, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 45]. Minister Kim Sung-hwan stated that nuclear power and renewable energy are not incompatible energy sources, suggesting the possibility of a harmonious energy mix [30, 44]. However, an analysis indicating that weather variability is affecting the profitability formula of renewable energy, and shaking wind speed, facility utilization rates, and even financial conditions, demonstrates that there are still many challenges to be addressed in expanding renewable energy [35]. Furthermore, heat pumps, which are considered an essential policy for achieving carbon neutrality, are also subject to ongoing debate due to high initial costs and energy tariff structures [12].

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸ”´ Intensification of the Global Climate Crisis and Growing Vulnerability
sections.content: Globally, the severe impacts of climate change are becoming visible, and concerns are growing, especially for vulnerable populations and regions. In Pakistan, climate justice protests have erupted due to grievances over severe floods and smog [8], while in the Alps, research has shown that glaciers are rapidly disappearing due to climate change and that fatalities from glacial floods are increasing [66, 80]. Furthermore, a study indicating that heat and humidity caused by climate change could increase stunting among children in South Asia warns of a severe threat to the growth of millions of children [50, 73, 74, 78]. These phenomena demonstrate that a global experiment is unfolding in real-time [60], and with the impacts of climate change even being mentioned during the Christmas season [49, 54], it suggests that the climate crisis is becoming a reality across all aspects of daily life.

sections.title: ğŸŒğŸŒ± The Bright and Dark Sides of Global Climate Action and Cooperation
sections.content: The international community is facing numerous challenges alongside various efforts to address climate change. The ASEAN region possesses renewable energy potential reaching 20 TW [32], and China is creating positive changes, such as successfully altering water flows through ambitious reforestation missions [69]. Furthermore, Asian farmers are combating climate change by utilizing biological control methods such as ducks, drones, and biopesticides [65], and the Canadian Ministry of Environment and Climate Change's forest and mangrove monitoring support program has also been implemented [72]. However, in the transition from COP30 to COP31, concerns are being raised that climate cooperation could weaken before emissions peak [61], and it is also pointed out that green industrial policies alone are insufficient for net-zero decarbonization [67]. Meanwhile, the news that the National Center for Atmospheric Research is slated for dissolution by the Trump administration signifies a significant setback for climate science research [81], and criticism that some media outlets report on net-zero 'separately' from climate change [59, 70] issues a warning that this could hinder public awareness and understanding of climate action.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the seriousness of the climate crisis, alongside the multifaceted response efforts underway both domestically and internationally. However, many challenges still remain, and we once again underscored the urgent need for enhanced international cooperation and the protection of the scientific research foundation. That concludes today's climate briefing.

summary.phenomenon: Since the first domestic wind turbine was commissioned in Jeju in 1975, Korea marks its 50th anniversary of wind power this year. However, the nation still relies on overseas sources for over 90% of its energy.
summary.cause: In the wake of the 1970s oil crisis, countries worldwide began developing alternative energy sources, with South Korea also initiating wind power generation.
